awd_titl_txt: Molecular Probes for Vibrational Imaging of Cellular Targets: Ions and Reactive Species
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) and Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms B (CSDM-B) programs in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Daniela Buccella and her research group at New York University are working to develop responsive molecular probes to investigate intracellular targets based on a technique called Raman spectroscopy. Microscopy techniques are ubiquitous tools in the study of biological analytes, allowing the detection of metal ions and reactive species in cells and tissues with high spatial and temporal resolution. The ability to track these species in real time is key to gaining insight on their roles in physiological and pathological processes. Raman-based microscopy has become increasingly valuable in this context, providing numerous advantages over conventional fluorescence microscopy techniques. An important drawback, however, is the low sensitivity and specificity of vibrational-based detection, for which many small and low abundance cellular targets still remain out of reach. To address this gap, this project seeks to develop novel indicators that are responsive to metal ions and reactive species, with the goal of imaging these species using a Raman technique to which they are currently invisible. This award also supports a partnership with faculty at Spelman College for the development of new laboratory and lecture modules that integrate chemistry and biology into a new capstone research course at Spelman.

This project focuses on establishing basic molecular platforms with Raman scattering properties that can be modulated in an analyte-dependent fashion. The work enables new vibrational imaging probes for stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) microscopy. The designed scaffolds take advantage of charge redistribution and modulation of electronic excited states to enable SRS- and electronic pre-resonance-SRS-based imaging of low abundance and transient cellular species that have small scattering cross sections of their own. Specific objectives include the development of recognition-based synthetic indicators for detecting biologically relevant metal ions and sensing pH, as well as reaction-based probes for sensing reactive oxygen species. The indicators are being applied toward turn-on and ratiometric detection modalities in cellulo, which have been particularly difficult to achieve for species that quench fluorescence, and therefore continue to pose a major challenge in bioimaging. In addition to the broader scientific impacts of the work, the project includes educational outreach activities targeting high school girls and college students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Microscopy techniques are ubiquitous tools in the study of biological systems as they enable tracking of key cellular components with high spatial and temporal resolution. Some cellular components, however, are incompatible with fluorescence—the spontaneous emission of light by molecules—that forms the basis of most microscopy-based imaging. To address this gap, this project investigated ways to modulate the vibrations of molecules in response to various cellular targets, with the goal of enabling their imaging by alternative microscopy techniques to which they are current invisible.

With this award, the PI Buccella developed ‘vibrational indicators’ for selective visualization of ions and reactive species at the cellular level using Raman-based techniques. Main outcomes of the project include the development of indicators for pH, Zinc(II), and a series of molecular reporters for important cellular reductants such as NADH and NADPH. Through a combination of computational and experimental approaches, the project yielded fundamental understanding of the mechanisms by which reaction with these targets leads to changes in the vibrational properties of molecular reporters, which will guide the design of new molecular probes in the future. Overall, the results represent an important advance in the field of molecular imaging and will facilitate the study of biological targets that have remained challenging to detect.

The project provided training opportunities at the interface of chemistry and biology to graduate and undergraduate students. It also served as the basis for summer and capstone projects for students from NYU and other institutions, including members of minoritized groups in science.


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Daniela Buccella
